verses.verse: (3 Sarai being barren giveth Hagar to Abram.4 Which conceiveth and despiseth her dame:6 And being ill handled, fleeth.7 The Angel comforteth her.11, 12 The name and manners of her son.13 She calleth upon the Lord, whom she findeth true.) Now (It seemeth that she had respect to God’s promise, which could not be accomplished without issue.) Sarai Abram’s wife bore him no children, and she had a maid an Egyptian, Hagar by name.

And Sarai said unto Abram, Behold now, the Lord hath (She faileth in binding God’s power to the common order of nature, as though God could not give her children in her old age.) restrained me from childbearing, I pray thee go in unto my maid: (Or, peradventure.) it may be that I shall (Hebrew, be built by her.) receive a child by her. And Abram obeyed the voice of Sarai.
Then Sarai Abram’s wife took Hagar her maid the Egyptian, after Abram had dwelled ten years in the land of Canaan, and gave her to her husband Abram for his wife.

¶ And he went in unto Hagar, and she conceived: and when she saw that she had conceived, her dame was (This punishment declareth what they gain that attempt anything against the word of God.) despised in her eyes.

Then Sarai said to Abram, (Hebrew, mine injury is upon thee.) Thou doest me wrong, I have given my maid into thy bosom, and she seeth that she hath conceived, and I am despised in her eyes: the Lord judge between me and thee.
Then Abram said to Sarai, Behold, thy maid is in thine (Or, power.) hand: do with her as it pleaseth thee. Then Sarai dealt roughly with her: wherefore she fled from her.
¶ But the (Which was Christ, as appeareth verse 13 and Gen. 18:17.) Angel of the Lord found her beside a fountain in the way of Shur,
And he said, Hagar Sarai’s maid, whence comest thou? and whither wilt thou go? And she said, I flee from my dame Sarai.
Then the Angel of the Lord said to her, (God rejecteth none estate of people in their misery, but sendeth them comfort.) Return to thy dame, and humble thyself under her hands.
Again the Angel of the Lord said unto her, I will so greatly increase thy seed, that it shall not be numbered for multitude.
Also the Angel of the Lord said unto her, See, thou art with child, and shalt bear a son, and shalt call his name Ishmael: for the Lord hath heard thy tribulation.

And he shall be a (Or, fierce and cruel, or; as a wild ass.) wild man: his hand shall be against every man, and every man’s hand against him, (Cross references: : Gen. 25:18) and (That is, the Ishmaelites shall be a peculiar people by themselves, and not a portion of another people.) he shall dwell in the presence of all his brethren.

Then she called the name of the Lord that spake unto her, Thou God lookest on me: for she said, (She rebuketh her own dullness and acknowledgeth God’s graces, who was present with her everywhere.) Have I not also here looked after him that seeth me?
(Gen. 24:62) Wherefore the Well was called, (Or, the well of the living, and seeing me.) Beer Lahai Roi: lo, it is between Kadesh and Bered.
¶ And Hagar bare Abram a son, and Abram called his son’s name which Hagar bare, Ishmael.
And Abram was four score and six years old when Hagar bare him Ishmael.
